metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: describe proper length (L₀) as the length that is measured in the frame of reference in which objects are at rest

proper_length_definition.name: Proper Length Definition
proper_length_definition.formula: L₀ = length measured at rest relative to object
proper_length_definition.correct: Proper length is measured when the observer is at rest relative to the object being measured. The object is stationary in that frame.

length measured when the object is movin.fix: Proper length requires the object to be AT REST in the observer's frame.
length measured when the object is movin.action: Ask: is the object moving in my frame? If yes, I measure contracted length.

the longest possible length.error: Partially right reasoning, but wrong definition.
the longest possible length.fix: Proper length IS the longest measurement, but it's defined by rest, not by being maximum.
the longest possible length.action: Define by measurement conditions, not by the result.

length measured from Earth.error: Earth is not always the rest frame.
length measured from Earth.fix: The rest frame depends on what you're measuring. A spaceship's proper length is measured on the spaceship.
length measured from Earth.action: The rest frame is wherever the object is stationary.

persistent.gap: You're not clear on what defines proper length.
persistent.action: Key test: is the object stationary relative to me? If yes, I measure proper length. Practice with train/platform examples.

rest_frame_identification.name: Rest Frame Identification
rest_frame_identification.formula: Rest frame = where object is stationary
rest_frame_identification.correct: The rest frame is the reference frame where the object being measured is not moving. Both ends of the object are at the same position relative to the observer.

the frame that is not accelerating.error: That's an inertial frame, not specifically a rest frame.
the frame that is not accelerating.fix: Rest frame is about relative motion, not acceleration. An inertial frame can still see objects moving.
the frame that is not accelerating.action: Inertial = not accelerating. Rest = object stationary relative to observer.

Earth's frame of reference.error: Earth is not always the rest frame.
Earth's frame of reference.fix: For a moving rocket, the rocket's frame is the rest frame for measuring the rocket's length.
Earth's frame of reference.action: Rest frame is object-specific. Different objects have different rest frames.

the frame with zero velocity.error: No frame has absolute zero velocity.
the frame with zero velocity.fix: Velocity is relative. Rest frame means zero velocity relative to the specific object.
the frame with zero velocity.action: A rocket at rest in its own frame is moving in Earth's frame. Both are valid.

persistent.gap: You're confusing absolute motion with relative motion.
persistent.action: Remember: there's no absolute rest. Rest frame is always relative to what you're measuring.

contracted_length_definition.name: Contracted Length Definition
contracted_length_definition.formula: L = length measured when object is moving
contracted_length_definition.correct: Contracted length is measured when the object is moving relative to the observer. The observer sees the object shortened in the direction of motion.

length measured at rest.fix: Contracted length requires relative motion between observer and object.
length measured at rest.action: If the object is moving past you, you measure contracted length.

length perpendicular to motion.error: Length perpendicular to motion is unchanged.
length perpendicular to motion.fix: Contraction only occurs in the direction of motion.
length perpendicular to motion.action: A rocket moving horizontally contracts horizontally, not vertically.

proper length divided by velocity.fix: L = L₀/γ, where γ is the Lorentz factor, not velocity.
proper length divided by velocity.action: The formula uses γ = 1/√(1 - v²/c²), not just v.

persistent.gap: You're mixing up proper and contracted length definitions.
persistent.action: Make a table: Proper = at rest = longest. Contracted = moving = shorter.

length_contraction_direction.name: Direction of Length Contraction
length_contraction_direction.formula: Contraction only in direction of motion
length_contraction_direction.correct: Length contraction occurs only in the direction of relative motion. Dimensions perpendicular to motion are unchanged.

in all three dimensions.error: Only the dimension along motion contracts.
in all three dimensions.fix: A moving rocket gets shorter in length but not in height or width.
in all three dimensions.action: If rocket moves along x-axis, only x-dimension contracts. y and z stay the same.

perpendicular to motion.error: Wrong direction. Perpendicular dimensions are unaffected.
perpendicular to motion.fix: Contraction is parallel to velocity, not perpendicular.
perpendicular to motion.action: Visualise a moving train: it gets shorter, not thinner.

in the direction the observer faces.error: Depends on motion, not observer orientation.
in the direction the observer faces.fix: What matters is the direction of relative velocity between object and observer.
in the direction the observer faces.action: If object moves left-right, it contracts left-right regardless of where you look.

persistent.gap: You're not visualising length contraction correctly.
persistent.action: Draw a rocket moving right. Only its length (horizontal) shrinks. Height stays same.

lorentz_factor_role.name: Lorentz Factor in Length Contraction
lorentz_factor_role.correct: The Lorentz factor γ determines how much contraction occurs. L = L₀/γ. As speed increases, γ increases, so L decreases.

equals 1 at high speeds.error: Opposite. γ = 1 at rest, and increases with speed.
equals 1 at high speeds.fix: At v = 0, γ = 1. As v → c, γ → infinity.
equals 1 at high speeds.action: Calculate γ at v = 0.5c, 0.9c, 0.99c. Watch it grow.

multiplied by proper length.error: That's time dilation. Length uses division.
multiplied by proper length.fix: Time: t = γt₀ (multiply). Length: L = L₀/γ (divide).
multiplied by proper length.action: Time dilates (gets bigger). Length contracts (gets smaller). Different operations.

is always greater than 2.fix: γ = 1.15 at v = 0.5c. γ = 2.29 at v = 0.9c. γ > 2 only above about 0.87c.
is always greater than 2.action: Check the formula: at low speeds, γ is barely above 1.

persistent.gap: You're not comfortable with how γ affects length.
persistent.action: Calculate L₀/γ for γ = 1, 2, 5, 10. See how length shrinks as γ grows.

length_contraction_formula.name: Length Contraction Formula
length_contraction_formula.correct: Contracted length equals proper length divided by the Lorentz factor. Since γ ≥ 1, contracted length is always less than or equal to proper length.

L = L₀γ.error: That would make contracted length longer. Wrong operation.
L = L₀γ.fix: L = L₀/γ. Dividing by γ (which is ≥ 1) makes L smaller.
L = L₀γ.action: Contracted means shorter. Dividing makes smaller. L = L₀/γ.

L = L₀ - γ.fix: The formula is L = L₀/γ, not L₀ - γ. Different mathematical operation.
L = L₀ - γ.action: Write out the formula: L = L₀/γ. The / means divide.

L = γ/L₀.fix: Proper length goes in numerator: L = L₀/γ.
L = γ/L₀.action: Larger proper length should give larger contracted length. Check: L₀/γ does this.

persistent.gap: You're getting the formula structure wrong.
persistent.action: Write L = L₀/γ ten times. Then calculate L for L₀ = 100 m and γ = 2, 4, 5.

proper_length_always_longest.name: Proper Length is Maximum
proper_length_always_longest.correct: Proper length is always the longest measurement of an object. All other observers measure a shorter (contracted) length.

contracted length can be longer.error: Never. Contracted length is always shorter.
contracted length can be longer.fix: L = L₀/γ and γ ≥ 1, so L ≤ L₀ always.
contracted length can be longer.action: Dividing by a number ≥ 1 can only make things equal or smaller.

they can be equal at any speed.error: Only equal when γ = 1, meaning v = 0.
they can be equal at any speed.fix: L = L₀ only when there's no relative motion.
they can be equal at any speed.action: When v = 0, γ = 1, so L = L₀/1 = L₀. Any motion makes L < L₀.

depends on the direction of motion.error: Proper length is always longest regardless of direction.
depends on the direction of motion.fix: Contraction occurs in the direction of motion, but proper length is still longest.
depends on the direction of motion.action: Moving left or right, the result is the same: contraction occurs.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why proper length is maximum.
persistent.action: Graph L vs v. At v = 0, L = L₀. As v → c, L → 0. Proper length is the peak.

relative_motion_symmetry.name: Relativity of Motion
relative_motion_symmetry.correct: If A sees B moving, then B sees A moving at the same speed in the opposite direction. Both perspectives are equally valid.

one frame is really moving.fix: Both frames are equally valid. Neither is really moving or really stationary.
one frame is really moving.action: Person on train sees platform move. Person on platform sees train move. Both correct.

faster frame experiences more contractio.error: Both frames see the other contracted.
faster frame experiences more contractio.fix: From train's view, platform is contracted. From platform's view, train is contracted.
faster frame experiences more contractio.action: This symmetry is key to relativity. Each sees the other contracted.

Earth is always the stationary frame.fix: A spaceship can consider itself stationary and Earth as moving.
Earth is always the stationary frame.action: All inertial frames are equivalent. None is preferred.

persistent.gap: You're holding onto the idea of absolute motion.
persistent.action: Practice switching perspectives. If train moves at v, platform moves at -v from train's view.

measurement_scenario_identification.name: Identifying Measurement Types
measurement_scenario_identification.correct: To identify the measurement type, ask: is the object stationary in my frame? If yes, I measure proper length. If the object is moving, I measure contracted length.

the observer determines it.error: The relative motion between observer and object determines it.
the observer determines it.fix: It's not about who you are, but whether the object moves relative to you.
the observer determines it.action: Same observer can measure proper OR contracted depending on which object.

proper length is measured with better in.error: Has nothing to do with instrument quality.
proper length is measured with better in.fix: Both measurements are equally accurate. They just measure different things.
proper length is measured with better in.action: Contracted length is not a measurement error. It's a real physical effect.

you must be on the object.error: You just need to be in the same frame, not physically on it.
you must be on the object.fix: An observer stationary relative to a spaceship measures proper length from anywhere in that frame.
you must be on the object.action: If you and the spaceship both have v = 0 in some frame, you measure its proper length.

persistent.gap: You're not using the correct criterion for identifying measurement types.
persistent.action: For every scenario, first ask: what object? Is it moving relative to the observer? Answer determines proper vs contracted.

train_platform_example.name: Train-Platform Scenarios
train_platform_example.formula: Each measures the other as contracted
train_platform_example.correct: Person on train measures proper length of train, contracted length of platform. Person on platform measures proper length of platform, contracted length of train.

train is contracted, platform is not.error: Both see the other as contracted.
train is contracted, platform is not.fix: From train's view, platform is contracted. From platform's view, train is contracted.
train is contracted, platform is not.action: This is the symmetry of special relativity. Neither is preferred.

whoever is really moving is contracted.error: No one is really moving. Motion is relative.
whoever is really moving is contracted.fix: Train person says platform moves. Platform person says train moves. Both correct.
whoever is really moving is contracted.action: There's no experiment to determine who is really moving.

only the shorter object is contracted.error: Contraction is about motion, not original size.
only the shorter object is contracted.fix: Both are contracted when viewed from the other's frame, regardless of their proper lengths.
only the shorter object is contracted.action: A 100 m train and 200 m platform both contract when viewed from the other.

persistent.gap: You're not applying symmetry correctly in scenarios.
persistent.action: Draw two columns: train's view and platform's view. Fill in what each measures.

particle_accelerator_application.name: Particle Accelerator Length
particle_accelerator_application.formula: Design uses proper length, particles see contracted
particle_accelerator_application.correct: Particle accelerators are designed using proper length (laboratory frame). High-speed particles see the accelerator as contracted in their frame.

particles see the accelerator as longer.error: Opposite. Moving particles see length contracted.
particles see the accelerator as longer.fix: In particle's frame, the accelerator is moving, so it's contracted.
particles see the accelerator as longer.action: Particle travels 1 km in lab frame, but sees only 100 m (if γ = 10) in its frame.

accelerator contracts in the lab frame.error: In lab frame, accelerator is at rest. No contraction.
accelerator contracts in the lab frame.fix: Proper length is measured in lab frame. Contraction only seen by particles.
accelerator contracts in the lab frame.action: Lab scientists measure proper length. They don't see their own accelerator contract.

length contraction doesn't affect accele.fix: Without accounting for relativity, particle behavior would be miscalculated.
length contraction doesn't affect accele.action: Drift tubes must be designed knowing particles see them as contracted.

persistent.gap: You're not applying length contraction to real scenarios.
persistent.action: Calculate: if γ = 10 and accelerator is 1 km, how long does a proton see it? (Answer: 100 m)

spaceship_journey_application.name: Spaceship Journey Distance
spaceship_journey_application.formula: Earth measures proper distance; ship sees contracted
spaceship_journey_application.correct: The distance between Earth and a star is measured as proper length by an Earth observer (both are stationary in Earth's frame). A traveling spaceship sees this distance as contracted.

spaceship measures proper distance.error: The spaceship is moving relative to the Earth-star system.
spaceship measures proper distance.fix: Earth and the star are stationary relative to each other. The ship is moving.
spaceship measures proper distance.action: Proper length of Earth-star distance is measured from Earth, not from moving ship.

distance is the same in both frames.fix: Ship sees shorter distance due to length contraction.
distance is the same in both frames.action: If Earth measures 10 light-years and γ = 2, ship sees 5 light-years.

the star moves toward the ship.error: From ship's view, yes, but this doesn't change who measures proper length.
the star moves toward the ship.fix: Ship sees everything moving, so ship measures contracted distances.
the star moves toward the ship.action: Motion is relative, but the Earth-star system is internally at rest.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying rest frames in journey scenarios.
persistent.action: Ask: what two points define the distance? Are they moving relative to each other? If no, that frame gives proper length.

definition.title: Understanding Proper Length
definition.instructions: Complete the statements about the definition of proper length.

sentences.text: Proper length (L₀) is defined as the length measured in a reference frame where the object being measured is {{d1}}. In this frame, both ends of the object remain at {{d2}} positions relative to the observer.

d1.tooltip: What is the key condition for measuring proper length?

d2.tooltip: If the object is stationary, its ends don't move relative to you.

sentences.text: The reference frame where an object is stationary is called the object's {{d3}} frame. An observer in this frame measures the {{d4}} length of the object.

d3.tooltip: What do we call the frame where something is at rest?

d4.tooltip: What type of length is measured in the rest frame?

sentences.text: Proper length is the {{d5}} measurement an observer can obtain for a given object. All other observers in relative motion will measure a {{d6}} length.

d5.tooltip: Is proper length the maximum or minimum possible measurement?

d6.tooltip: What happens to measured length when there's relative motion?

reference_frames.title: Reference Frames and Length Measurement
reference_frames.instructions: Complete the statements about how reference frames affect length measurement.

sentences.text: According to special relativity, there is no {{d1}} reference frame. All inertial frames are {{d2}} valid for describing physical phenomena.

d1.tooltip: Einstein showed no frame is special or preferred.

d2.tooltip: The laws of physics work the same in all inertial frames.

sentences.text: When a train moves past a platform, passengers on the train consider themselves to be {{d3}}, while observers on the platform consider the {{d4}} to be stationary.

d3.tooltip: From the passengers' perspective, they aren't moving.

d4.tooltip: Platform observers see themselves as not moving.

sentences.text: Both observers agree on their {{d5}} speed, but they disagree about which reference frame is {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What type of speed do both observers agree on?

d6.tooltip: Each thinks the other is the one moving.

contracted_length.title: Understanding Contracted Length
contracted_length.instructions: Complete the statements about contracted length.

sentences.text: Contracted length (L) is measured when the object is {{d1}} relative to the observer. The observer sees the object as {{d2}} in the direction of motion.

d1.tooltip: What condition causes an observer to measure contracted length?

d2.tooltip: What happens to the apparent length of a moving object?

sentences.text: Length contraction only occurs in the direction {{d3}} to the relative motion. Dimensions {{d4}} to the motion remain unchanged.

d3.tooltip: In which direction does the object appear shorter?

d4.tooltip: Which dimensions are NOT affected by length contraction?

sentences.text: The relationship between contracted and proper length is given by L = L₀/γ, where γ is the {{d5}} factor. Since γ is always ≥ 1, contracted length is always {{d6}} than proper length.

d5.tooltip: What is the name of the factor γ = 1/√(1 - v²/c²)?

d6.tooltip: Dividing by a number ≥ 1 makes the result smaller.

identifying_lengths.title: Identifying Proper and Contracted Length
identifying_lengths.instructions: Complete the statements about identifying length types in scenarios.

sentences.text: To determine if you measure proper or contracted length, ask: is the object {{d1}} in my frame? If yes, you measure {{d2}} length.

d1.tooltip: What condition means you measure proper length?

d2.tooltip: When the object is at rest, what type of length do you measure?

sentences.text: A passenger on a train measures the {{d3}} length of the train, because the train is {{d4}} relative to the passenger.

d3.tooltip: The train is stationary in the passenger's frame.

d4.tooltip: From the passenger's perspective, is the train moving?

sentences.text: An observer on a platform measures the {{d5}} length of a passing train, because the train is {{d6}} relative to the platform.

d5.tooltip: The train is moving in the platform's frame.

d6.tooltip: From the platform's perspective, is the train moving?

definition.title: Applying Proper Length Concepts
definition.instructions: Apply your understanding of proper length to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A spaceship crew measuring their own ship's length obtains the {{d1}} length, since they share the ship's {{d2}} frame.

d1.tooltip: The crew is at rest relative to the ship.

d2.tooltip: The crew and ship are stationary relative to each other.

sentences.text: When scientists on Earth measure the length of a passing comet's tail, they measure a {{d3}} length because the comet is {{d4}} relative to Earth.

d3.tooltip: The comet is moving in Earth's frame.

d4.tooltip: A comet flying past Earth is not stationary relative to Earth.

sentences.text: The proper length of a muon's journey from creation to Earth's surface would be measured by an observer on {{d5}}, not by the {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Earth and its atmosphere are stationary relative to each other.

d6.tooltip: The muon sees the distance as contracted because it's moving.

reference_frames.title: Working with Reference Frames
reference_frames.instructions: Apply reference frame reasoning to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A train passenger and a platform observer each claim to be stationary. This apparent contradiction is resolved by recognising that motion is {{d1}}, not {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What key principle of relativity resolves this?

d2.tooltip: There is no absolute standard of rest.

sentences.text: From the platform's frame, the train is contracted. From the train's frame, the {{d3}} is contracted. Both observations are {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Each sees the other as moving, hence contracted.

d4.tooltip: Special relativity allows both perspectives to be correct.

sentences.text: If an astronaut measures a planet to be 12,000 km in diameter while flying past at 0.8c, this is a {{d5}} measurement. The planet's proper diameter is {{d6}} than 12,000 km.

d5.tooltip: The planet is moving in the astronaut's frame.

d6.tooltip: Proper length is always the longest measurement.

contracted_length.title: Calculating Contracted Length
contracted_length.instructions: Apply the length contraction formula to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A rocket with proper length 100 m travels at 0.8c, where γ = 1.67. An observer on Earth measures its length as {{d1}} m, using the formula L = {{d2}}.
At very high speeds approaching c, the Lorentz factor γ approaches {{d3}}, causing contracted length to approach {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: As v → c, what happens to γ = 1/√(1 - v²/c²)?

d4.tooltip: As γ → infinity, what happens to L = L₀/γ?

sentences.text: A particle accelerator is 1000 m long in the laboratory frame. A proton with γ = 5 travelling through it measures the accelerator's length as {{d5}} m, because the accelerator is {{d6}} in the proton's frame.

d6.tooltip: From the proton's view, the accelerator moves past it.

identifying_lengths.title: Applying Identification Skills
identifying_lengths.instructions: Identify the type of length measurement in each scenario.

sentences.text: An astronaut measures the distance between Earth and a star as 8 light-years while travelling at 0.6c. The astronaut measures a {{d1}} distance because Earth and the star are {{d2}} relative to the astronaut.

d1.tooltip: The Earth-star system is moving in the astronaut's frame.

d2.tooltip: From the spaceship, the entire Earth-star system moves past.

sentences.text: The same Earth-star distance measured by an observer on Earth is the {{d3}} length, which equals {{d4}} than 8 light-years.

d3.tooltip: Earth and the star are at rest relative to each other.

d4.tooltip: Proper length is always the longest measurement.

sentences.text: To measure the proper length of a relativistic particle's track, scientists must be in the {{d5}} frame, which is the {{d6}} frame.

d5.tooltip: Proper length is measured in the rest frame of the object.

d6.tooltip: The particle sees itself as stationary.

definition.title: Mastering Proper Length Concepts
definition.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of proper length.

sentences.text: The reason proper length L₀ is always the longest measurement is mathematical: since L = L₀/γ and γ ≥ {{d1}}, the ratio L/L₀ is always ≤ {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What is the minimum value of γ?

d2.tooltip: Dividing by a number ≥ 1 gives a result ≤ 1.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that proper means correct and contracted means wrong. In reality, {{d3}} measurements are equally valid. Proper refers to the {{d4}} condition, not accuracy.

d3.tooltip: Both measurements are physically correct in their frames.

d4.tooltip: Proper describes the frame condition, not measurement quality.

sentences.text: The key criterion for identifying proper length is not which observer makes the measurement, but whether the object is {{d5}} in the observer's {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What condition defines proper length measurement?

d6.tooltip: Rest is defined relative to a reference frame.

reference_frames.title: Synthesising Reference Frame Concepts
reference_frames.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of reference frame reasoning.

sentences.text: The symmetry of length contraction can seem paradoxical: train passengers see the platform contracted, while platform observers see the train contracted. This is consistent because {{d1}} depends on the observer's {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Different observers can have different measurements.

d2.tooltip: Frame of reference determines measurement results.

sentences.text: Einstein's key insight was that {{d3}} motion does not exist. Therefore, asking which object is really contracted has {{d4}} answer.

d3.tooltip: What type of motion did Einstein show doesn't exist?

d4.tooltip: Without absolute motion, there's no absolute contraction.

sentences.text: Both train and platform observers agree on their {{d5}} velocity, the {{d6}} of light, and the laws of physics, but disagree on which object is contracted.

d5.tooltip: They agree on how fast they move relative to each other.

d6.tooltip: One of Einstein's postulates is about this quantity.

contracted_length.title: Advanced Length Contraction
contracted_length.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of length contraction concepts.

sentences.text: Length contraction is a real physical effect, not an optical illusion. A muon travelling at 0.99c experiences the atmosphere's depth as {{d1}} than Earth observers measure, which explains why muons reach the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: The muon sees a contracted distance through the atmosphere.

d2.tooltip: Length contraction explains how muons travel further than classical physics predicts.

sentences.text: For particle accelerator design, engineers use the {{d3}} length of drift tubes. Particles travelling at relativistic speeds see these tubes as {{d4}}, affecting timing calculations.

d3.tooltip: The accelerator is at rest in the laboratory.

d4.tooltip: From the particle's view, the drift tubes are moving.

sentences.text: At v = 0.866c, γ = 2, so contracted length equals {{d5}} of proper length. At v = 0.99c, γ ≈ 7, so contracted length is about {{d6}} of proper length.

identifying_lengths.title: Expert Length Identification
identifying_lengths.instructions: Demonstrate expert-level ability to identify measurement types.

sentences.text: A spaceship travels from Earth to Alpha Centauri. The 4.3 light-year distance is the {{d1}} length because it's measured from a frame where both Earth and Alpha Centauri are {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Earth and the star system are at rest relative to each other.

d2.tooltip: Both endpoints are at rest in the same frame.

sentences.text: Interestingly, the spaceship crew measures a {{d3}} distance for the same journey, explaining how they can complete a 4.3 light-year trip in less than 4.3 years of {{d4}} time.

d3.tooltip: The crew sees the distance as contracted.

d4.tooltip: Time passes differently in different frames too.

sentences.text: The resolution to the muon paradox involves {{d5}} perspectives: Earth observers see muon clocks run slow, while muons see Earth's atmosphere as {{d6}}. Both explanations give the same result.

d5.tooltip: Both perspectives are valid and consistent.

d6.tooltip: The muon sees the atmosphere as a shorter distance.
